title: Memoirs of the Life of Sir Walter Scott, Volume 6
author: Lockhart, J. G. (John Gibson)
snippet: Fife,[108] to mamma's great surprise and scandal, chose     to stay at Abbotsford with Mai, and plainly denied to follow the     carriage--so our canine establishment in Castle Street is reduced     to little Ury.[109] We spent two days at Arniston, on the     road,--and on coming here, found Sophia as nicely and orderly     settled in her house as if she had been a married woman these     five years.

title: The journal of Sir Walter Scott,

snippet: 1 Lord Justice-Clerk; Lord President ; 2 Captain Scarlett, 3 a gentlemanlike young man, the son of the great Counsel, 4 and a friend of my son Walter ; Lady Charlotte Hope, and other woman-kind ; R. Dundas of Arniston, and his pleasant and good- humoured little wife, whose quick intelligent look pleases me more, though her face be plain, than a hundred mechanical beauties.

title: Waverley novels.
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: " Ye cannot spoil it, Alan," said my father, rubbing his hands with much complacency; " that isthe very cream of the business, man—it is just, asI said before, a subject upon whilk all the tyroneshave been trying their whittles for fifteen years;and as there have been about ten or a dozen agentsconcerned, and each took his own way, the case iscome to that pass, that Stair or Arniston could notmend it; and I do not think even you, Alan, cando it much harm—ye may get credit by it, but yecan lose none."

title: Story of Maurice Lestrange. Being an account of his travels and adventures in Scotland during the year 1765. [A tale.]
author: Omond, George William Thomson.
snippet: Mr Carlyleand I had spent a long day on the battlefield ofPrestonpans; and Mr Henry Dundas had carried meto Arniston, the residence of his elder brother, who wasthen the President of the Law Courts in Scotland,and who, though a very busy man, immersed in graveaffairs of the State, found time to give much attentionto the improvement of his property, and was also avery genial and kindly host.

title: Story of Maurice Lestrange. Being an account of his travels and adventures in Scotland during the year 1765. [A tale.]
author: Omond, George William Thomson.
snippet: The Scots wantedto have a Militia of their own, but the Governmentin London would not hear of it, on the groundthat it was not safe to arm our people so soonafter the affair of '45 ; and Dundas of Arniston, whohad a great say with the Government, made a bigspeech against the Scots Militia in the House ofCommons.
